RE: [junit] cannot run testing with UI TestRunner?Ok kids, let's all relax =
and think happy thoughts.  JUnit  is good.  Class loaders are your friends.=
  :)

The central issue here is:

JUnit's default class loader, let's call =
it ReloadingTestSuiteLoader, causes some people grief.  At the same time, i=
t also saves some people grief.  Thus we have conflict in paradise.  The "q=
uick fix" for those who experience grief is to say "-noloading".  If only w=
e knew about that ahead of time, then we could avoid said grief.  For those=
 who don't experience grief, there is no quick fix because, as the saying g=
oes, it ain't broke.

To complicate the issue, the ReloadingTestSuiteLoader=
 is a "magic feature".  A "magic feature" is a feature that you don't know =
is there - it does its magic silently.  They are often undocumented.  Unles=
s someone told you it was there, you wouldn't necessarily know about it.  M=
agic features are your friends, except when they're not.  The unfortunate t=
hing about this magic feature is that one often doesn't find out about unti=
l it causes them grief.  They learn about it the hard way.  It's great whil=
e it works, until it doesn't.

I feel that the "Q: I have grief. A: say -no=
loader." pattern appears on the discussion group frequently enough so as to=
 be deemed "a problem".  Let's face it, the ReloadingTestSuiteLoader is a m=
ixed blessing.  It's not well documented, but once you know about it, it's =
cool.

What to do?  I say keep the feature (and all of its blessings), but =
don't make it the default behavior.  I.e., don't put people in a position t=
hat they have to find out the hard way.  Let's cause JUnit 3.6 to have a "-=
loader" flag that would enable the ReloadingTestSuiteLoader.  When that fla=
g isn't given, then JUnit will use Java's default class loader.  Then, JUni=
t's default class loading behavior will be Java's default class loading beh=
avior.  It's more intuitive that way anyway.

Discussion is warmly invited,=
 as long as it's professional.  Flames to NLA0:

Cheers!

_chas_
